My fear is that too many woemn are being under treated only to come back to 2 to 5 yrs with another tumor.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 02:45AM - edited Jan 31, 2011 02:47AM by motherofpatient OMG, OMG I went to the Am Cancer site on tea tree oil - SOOOOOO glad Lago posted about this. It is a dangerous drug and should not be used by cancer patients. I found sites selling products with it in and with no cautions about the estrogen production. WOW - so many things to learn. I will NOT be giving it to my daughter when it arrives. So very glad I found out about it before hand. THANKS. Even things suggested on this site must be investigated since every woman's cancer is different - especially the differences among the ER and PR rate of expression. As for ice mitts and socks - How cold do they need to be?

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2011 04:04AM - edited Feb 17, 2011 04:06AM by motherofpatient My daughter had a negative biopsy on a second spot that, when the surgeon removed it anyway - it was cancer, too. In your case if both areas were removed and tested, you would have a better picture of what is going on. If they are telling you that you need tamox, then you must have a hormone positive cancer. I don't think tamox is a routine preventive drug. Can you get another doctor to take your case? Sounds like you need to go outside the system you are in. Can you get copies of the test results and all your medical history? It is always a good idea to get your own copies.

The two people running it were involved in a charity scam in MS during Katrina called Camp Coastal Outpost and the Attorney General and Secretary of State, along with the IRS, are after them. Donations were used for bar bilss and vacations. Their new web site has a button for "how can I help" to get donations. They are not registeed as and charity and have never been one.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 01:59PM motherofpatient wrote: Be careful when you read information  - first thing is to find out what the person's diagnosis is. Stage IIa and mean two different situaitons, one with node involvement and one with a larger tumor, so the actual recommendation from the onco may be different for each individual. Also, so  many people don't post their age or menopausal status - very important. Also the PR and ER percentages because ER+ adn/or PR+ means different things based on how high the percentage is. So what works for one doesn't for others. Also, if you have mixed DCIS and invasive then the treatment might be different. By all means do your research but be careful to compare apples to apples. The surgeon that is caring for my daughter is highly respected by everyone we have come into contact with, and the oncologist she will see has a doctorate in pharmacology and an MD from a respected institution. She does reseach on premenopausal women with breast cancer, so we feel she is on top of it, BUT we still read everything we can and bring written questions to every meeting. Before we see the onco on the 13th I am getting a recording devise, in my day we called then tape recorders, I don't know what to call it now, but I'm getting one. I'm sure the clerk at Brookstone will know what I mean. Good wishes and gentle thoughts to all of you.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 05:06AM - edited Mar 1, 2011 05:07AM by motherofpatient Yes, our soil, our environment, the poison in our food all contributes to cancer, but to say the Chinese women don't get cancer as often is suspect. The fact is that most women in China do not have access to medical care and the government puts out whatever stats they feel make them look good as they did during the AIDS epidemic. When the government controls all the information released it is difficult to accept any information they produce.
